title: man burp rare condition botox injections throat
story: Neil Ribbens, 34, lost the ability to belch as a baby and spent almost his entire left in agony after meals as he couldnt release gas from his stomach.He visited multiple doctors over the years and all were left stumped - but earlier this year he came across an experimental treatment more commonly associated with smoothing out wrinkles.And since undergoing the 40-minute procedure at the private BMI The Alexandra Hospital in Greater Manchester, Neil says hes been burping like a frog.The record label talent spotter told the Manchester Evening News its the best thing that could have happened.He added: “I’m more confident, I’m healthier and I just feel all round so much happier.Neil explained that eating a large meal, drinking alcohol or fizzy drinks would trigger crippling stomach aches and violent hiccups.His belly would bloat to more than twice its usual size and make strange gurgling sounds from the bottom of his throat, which he described as the strangest sound youve ever heard coming from a human body.He added: “That was the end game and would put me on my back for a while. It would feel like I’d really been through the mill.”His inability to burp resulted in him having to release trapped wind in less favourable ways and he says he became very good at releasing gas downstairs.Medics would prescribe various over-the-counter drugs but nothing worked - and one doctor even laughed in his face.But earlier thus year he came across Dr Yakubu Karagama who is pioneering the £3,000 private procedure not yet available on the NHS.Botox, which is a relaxant, was injected into Neils tense larynx to loosen it and allow gas to escape from his throat.Neil said: “Words can’t really describe how much better I feel now and, luckily, unlike cosmetic Botox, it won’t have to be repeated at monthly intervals. The one operation should have cured my problem for good.”

title: florida rollercoaster derails daytona beach riders dangling
story: Firefighters scrambled to Florida amusement park just after 8.30pm local time last night to rescue 10 people from the Sandblaster ride.Six were rushed to hospital after suffering from unknown injuries, and two remain in a critical condition.Local reports claim some passengers were trapped for up to 30 minutes after the rollercoaster suffered a malfunction.Shocking pictures which emerged from the scene showed Daytona Beach firefighters straddling the apparatus of the ride, to rescue people trapped in the suspended car.A harrowing video later uploaded filmed a desperate woman crawling along the tracks assisted by fire crews to safety.Sasha Staton, spokeswoman for the Daytona Beach Fire Department, said there were four people in the front car - two of which fell approximately 34ft to the ground.She told local newspaper news-journal: “Daytona Beach Firefighters did an amazing job tonight rescuing the 10 very frightened passengers on the rollercoaster.“They were faced with dangerous conditions as they worked as fast as possible to successfully extricate everyone safely.”The Daytona Beach News Journal reported the rollercoaster is called the Sand Blaster and is 85ft high with more than a half-mile of track.It opened on the current site in Florida in August 2013 after it was bought from a closed amusement park in Delaware - at that point it was 40-years-old.

title: mum passport british polish joanna banks
story: Joanna Banks has a Polish mother who never put her British fathers name on her birth certificate when born in Hull, East Yorks.When she enquired about a passport for the summer holiday, officials said her nationality was from the east European country and must get a Polish passport.Then, they added, she could pass a citizenship test costing £1,500 to become British.Exasperated Joanna, who speaks with a broad Yorkshire accent, said: I was in tears. I have been punished.Ive never even left the country and wanted to take my three children abroad for the first time.In my eyes I have always been British, born and bred in Hull. I cant afford a citizenship test.She explained her mother Gener split from her father when she was pregnant but they later got back together and married - but he has since died.Gener said: Shes not even been in Poland.Hull east Labour MP Karl turner has written to Home Secretary Sajid Javid to review Joannas case.He added: It is an appalling story. This is a British citizen - as British as I am - not an illegal immigrant.The Home Office said it was awaiting a passport application from Joanna.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: woman chained bed 20 years argentina
story: Marisa Almiron, 42, was rescued by cops in Venado Tuerto, Argentina, in a disturbing case which bears striking similarities to the infamous crimes of Josef Fritzl in Austria.Authorities were alerted after a neighbour reportedly heard the victims blood-curdling screams.Police found Marisa tied naked to her filthy bed surrounded by her own excrement, according to local media.She reportedly had clear signs of malnutrition and is said to be psychologically affected by her alleged 20-year confinement.Marisa was taken to Hospital Alejandro Gutierrez in the city, located in the south-west of the country, where she continues to received treatment.According to reports, her father allegedly enslaved her as a young woman because she had a boyfriend.Other family members allegedly knew what was happening, according to a neighbour.She was finally rescued when the local resident alerted police, reports new outlet Perfil.The neighbour said: My home became a living hell because of the screams I could hear through the walls.“That woman suffered a lot of bad things.The heroic local said she had been reporting the alleged enslavement for years but police never acted on her warnings.When the authorities did arrive, the family allegedly refused to let them into the house and insisted they needed a warrant.They allegedly said they kept her chained to her bed because she had psychological problems, according to reports.Local media reports no arrests have been made as the investigation continues.In the depraved Fritzl case, sadistic sex attacker Josef held his daughter Elizabeth captive for 24 years after he became enraged with the then 18-year-old constantly partying with other teenagers.Fritzl fathered seven children with his daughter during her imprisonment in a fortified basement underneath his home.There is no suggestion at this stage that the Argentinian woman suffered sexual abuse at the hands of her family.In March 2009, he was jailed for life while Elizabeth and her children were given new identities.

title: sharp object asda little angels nappies
story: Laura Ashton, 22, claims she pulled out the mystery object from the lining of the Little Angels nappy.She was getting her daughters Millie, five, and toddler Gracie-May ready for the school run in Stafford, Staffs when she made the shocking discovery.Laura asked Millie to film her when she allegedly found a sharp object in the nappy — which she got from a 72-pack bought for £4.98.Mum-of-two Laura said: As I opened it up I noticed something dark in the middle so rubbed my fingers across it.It felt quite pointy so I told Millie to film me opening it up.She added: After a few seconds I managed to tear out a sharp, dark object. It felt quite light but it was really sharp.At first I thought it was a piece of machinery but God knows what it was.Millie was shouting chuck it in the fire. We then started going through a few more to see if anything else dangerous was lurking in there.Im just so shocked. If I hadnt spotted it that could have pierced through and really hurt Gracie-May.Laura contacted Asda to report finding the object on Monday morning — and later returned the packet of nappies to her local shop.Laura shared her terrifying discovery on a Facebook video which has clocked up 430,000 views and has been shared almost 6,000 times.The support worker said: I did it to raise awareness among my family and friends as I was just outraged with what had happened.You just dont know how many times this has happened and people have let it slide. Others mums have messaged me thanking me.There needs to be safer regulations as babies are so precious.A spokesman for Asda said: We are extremely proud of our Little Angels nappies and we take complaints of this nature very seriously.Our nappies are produced on an enclosed line within a sealed environment, so the first time the packet is opened is by the customer.If the door of the production line is opened, the conveyor belt stops and any nappies on the line are rejected.We have stringent processes in place to ensure there is no contamination within this robust process.We would like to thank Ms Ashton for contacting us and as soon as we receive the nappy we will run a full and thorough investigation to understand what happened.

title: france eu scrap english eu main language
story: The Gallic mother tongue of our baguette-munching neighbours was the default language in EU institutions before the UK joined the bloc in 1973.But with Britain voting to leave the union, brazen French President Macron wants Brussels to move away from English despite it being the most widely spoken language on the continent, reports the Wall Street Journal.He said: “English has probably never been so present in Brussels as when we’re talking about Brexit.“This domination is not inevitable.”And the bizarre French-language revolution in the European parliament has already begun.Macron’s recently appointed ambassador to the EU, Philippe Léglise-Costa walked out of a budget meeting in April because English was being used.A Nordic diplomat, who was in the room, said: “Everyone was happy to speak in English, but once he made a fuss the others also started demanding interpretation into their national languages.“They got their French interpretation for the next meeting.“But I’m sure eventually everyone will start talking English again.”Macron, 40, who became France’s youngest president in 2017, has also pledged to offer French classes to EU officials and invest in international French-speaking schools.Another ally in his bid to restore French is EU President Jean-Claude Juncker who hails from neighbouring Luxembourg.While speaking on TV in France recently, he said: “Why would Shakespeare’s language be superior to that of Voltaire?”“We are wrong to have become so anglicised.”

title: benedict cumberbatch david walliams and lily cole join thanksgiving service for stephen hawking at westminster abbey
story: The award-winning cosmologist was celebrated for his unique example of achievement against all the odds as crowds including Little Britain star David Walliams, music legend Nile Rodgers and model Lily Cole gathered at Westminster Abbey.More than 1,000 people attended the service of thanksgiving for the physicist, who died in March aged 76 after living with motor neuron disease for 55 years.Benedict Cumberbatch, who played Hawking in a 2004 BBC drama, gave a reading on wisdom as the ashes of the renowned physicist were interred in Scientists Corner, between the graves of Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin.An address was also given by two of Professor Hawking’s oldest scientist friends, Lord Rees, the astronomer royal, and Kip Thorne, an American physicist and Nobel prizewinner.Rees, who first met Prof Hawking at the University of Cambridge in the early 60s, paid tribute to the scientists great contributions to the world.Lord Rees said: Stephen described his own scientific quest as learning the mind of God, but this was a metaphor.He shared Darwins agnosticism, but it is fitting that he too should be interred in this national shrine.His name will live in the annals of science. Nobody else since Einstein has done more to deepen our understanding of space, time and gravity.Millions have had their horizons widened by his books and lectures, and even more worldwide have been inspired by a unique example of achievement against all the odds.Choral music echoed through the grand building as family members, led by the Dean of Westminster, processed to Prof Hawkings final resting place.A memorial stone will lie above Professor Hawkings grave, inscribed with his most famous black hole equation, hovering over a series of rings.The message: Here lies what was mortal of Stephen Hawking 1942 - 2018 has also been engraved on the memorial stone.The grave was designed by John Maine and is made from Caithness slate from the north of Scotland - was chosen to represent deep space.Hawkings life story, let alone his work, has inspired millions.At the age of just 22, he was diagnosed with a rare form of motor neurone disease and given just a few years to live.His illness left him wheelchair-bound and dependent on a computerised voice system for communication.However, he defied all odds, going on to become a towering figure in the world of physics, a bestselling author particularly with his book A Brief History Of Time, a father of three and a TV celebrity.Professor Hawkings words have also been set to an original score by Greek composer Vangelis, which will be beamed into space towards the nearest black hole.Professor Hawkings daughter, Lucy, said the music would be aimed at the nearest black hole, 1A 0620-00.It is a message of peace and hope, about unity and the need for us to live together in harmony on this planet”, she said.Lucy, and first wife Jane Hawking, were among those who laid flowers, while a medal created by the Stephen Hawking Foundation was also placed in the grave next to the wooden casket.Professor Hawkings children have expressed their gratitude to the abbey for allowing their father to have a distinguished final resting place.Friend and former colleague Nobel Prize winner Kip Thorne remembered the inspiring physicist for his sense of humour and legendary love for life.He said: Stephen and I were very close friends for 43 years, he was by far the most stubborn friend I ever had.He absolutely refused to let his physical disability get in the way of doing great science or get in the way of having great fun.He added: He has earned a special place in the hearts of admirers worldwide and a special place here in Westminster Abbey, alongside Isaac Newton.The most recent burials of scientists there were those of Ernest Rutherford, a pioneer of nuclear physics, in 1937, and Joseph John Thomson, who discovered electrons, in 1940.One thousand people from more than 100 countries were invited following a ballot that attracted 25,000 applications.Guests were welcomed by volunteers from the opening ceremony of the 2012 London Paralympic Games.

title: eid al fitr celebrated in birmingham with record 140000 people turn out
story: Worshippers from around the world descended on the city’s Small Heath Park for the Eid festivities.The Celebrate Eid event - the largest of its kind in Europe - has seen a ten-fold increase in attendees since 12,000 took part in the first one in 2011.Muslims of all ages came together for morning prayers, before enjoying festivities including fairground rides, miniature golf and laser clay pigeon shooting.Food and drink from local stalls was also on offer, and organisers from Green Lane Masjid and Community Centre heralded the events continuing success and growing popularity.A spokesman for the organisation said: This celebration is one of the most important in the Islamic religious calendar and its an opportunity for us all to come together in peace and unity.Were all overwhelmed that so many people from different faiths and from across the world have travelled to Birmingham for this years Celebrate Eid.Weve been working for months with five local mosques and our charity partner Human Appeal to organise the community for a memorable day of prayer, games and fun.Ramadan is also a time for charitable giving, and the mosque and community centre said it had raised more than £1 million for the Saving Syria Project.More than 200 volunteers are helping to clear up the park, once the festivities have concluded.Ramadan is the holiest month in the Muslim calendar, where Muslims focus on personal reflection and prayer through three types of worship: charity, prayer and fasting.This year’s Ramadan began on May 16 before finishing yesterday.For its duration Muslims are required to fast from dawn to sunset, with a pre-dawn meal known as suhur and sunset meal called ifta.Children and those suffering from an illness, travelling, are elderly, pregnant, breastfeeding, diabetic, chronically ill or menstruating are excluded from the fast.It is followed by another two days of festivity for the global Muslim community, which numbers over 1.6 billion.

title: uk weather sun after storm hector mini heatwave next week
story: A high of 23.6C was recorded in Gravesend, Kent today as the South enjoyed balmy blue skies and long sunny spells.Photos from the Kent and Sussex coasts show sun-seekers hitting the beach to soak up the weather and enjoy a warm welcome to the weekend.But grey skies hung over Northern England, Scotland and Northern Ireland today as rain showers swept in off the back of Storm Hector.Temperatures here struggled to reach the mid-teens as the UKs weather map split into a north-south divide.Next week will bring more settled conditions as temperatures creep up to the mid-twenties — although the good weather may still focus more on southerly areas.Met Office forecaster Charles Powell told The Sun: There will still be some changeable weather for some with systems coming in from the West next week.It will be breezy in the northern half of the UK with some fairly brisk winds and a cooler feel as temperatures reach the high teens.But the more South and South East you go the drier and warmer it will be.On Tuesday temperatures could pick up to 25C or 26C as a gradual settling down process spreads across the South.First, many parts of the UK will have to put up with a mix of sunshine, cloud and rain this weekend — as well as cooler temperatures reaching only the high teens.A band of heavy rain will move in from the West tomorrow, affecting Northern Ireland, North West England and Scotland throughout the day.And on Sunday, a similar but weaker band of rain will rinse Wales and the South West.Mr Powell added: It will be a changeable weekend with different weather fronts affecting different parts of the country — but by the middle of next week it should be more settled for most.

title: hundreds of brits to get higher benefits after latest change to the rules
story: Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey announced today that 1,000 claimants are likely to see a rise in their benefits in coming months.It comes after she pulled out of a court case against a disabled claimant whod had their payouts cut.The anonymous claimant - who suffers from diabetes and dyslexia - won a tribunal judgment stating that the level of benefits they deserved had been underestimated by officials.They should have got an extra £57.30 a week - around £2,800 a year - from the daily living allowance.Ms McVey this week scrapped an appeal against the tribunals ruling.And today she confirmed the knock-on effect will be around 1,000 other disabled people getting a hike in the amount of money they get in Personal Independence Payment.Although the exact benefits increase for each claimant is not yet confirmed, it is likely to be similar to the applicant in the court case.The minister said: I carefully considered this appeal and have decided to not continue with it in order to provide certainty to the claimant involved.I am pleased to confirm the claimant will be receiving arrears of benefit as soon as possible.She added that her officials are now working to apply the rules to fit the tribunals interpetration of the existing law.Ms McVey said: This work will include a review exercise later in the year. We expect that around 1,000 claimants will be affected.I am absolutely committed to ensuring that disabled people and people with health conditions get the right support they need.The Work and Pensions Secretary faced embarrassment this morning when a damning report blasted the roll-out of the flagship Universal Credit benefits reform.

title: woman shaving legs new york subway
story: She seems completely oblivious to the shocked commuters around her at the Times Square stop.The lady even took the time to apply some shaving foam to her limbs before beginning her very public grooming routine.One man sitting on the same bench looked particularly disgusted when he noticed what is going on just feet away.Shockingly, some people did not even react to the odd ritual, having probably seen far stranger on the subway.In a separate incident, commuters were left horrified when a druggie high on a Zombie drug  passed out on train tracks on Tuesday.Shocking footage showed the moment a 51-year-old man reportedly high on Spice fell off the platform at Myrtle and Broadway station.The man appeared to try and pick himself up, but could only roll onto his side.Seconds later, another man, 48, was filmed lying on subway platform, barely conscious but trying to move his trousers.Taiberious Carr, who filmed the antics, said the mans face was electrocuted as he fell off onto the tracks, causing his skin to burn.Mr Carr said police were called immediately after he was spotted, but no one rushed to his aid because they feared being electrocuted.He can be heard saying: I damn sure aint no paramedic but it doesnt take a rocket scientist to figure out he was electrocuted from the third rail.

title: wayne coleen rooney car towed beyonce jay z concert manchester
story: The England legends £130,000 car was seen being hauled onto a tow truck on Wednesday evening outside Manchester Citys stadium.It happened shortly before the latest gig in Beyonce and Jay-Zs On The Run II tour.A ticket on the cars windscreen said the vehicle had caused an unnecessary obstruction.The Sun Online has contacted Wayne and Coleens representatives for comment.Manchester City Council sets removal costs of up to £105.But the price of the modified Range Rover ranges from £85,000 to £130,000.Wayne, who now plays for boyhood club Everton, admitted drink-driving and handed a two year driving ban in September last year.The dad was stopped by police while driving party girl Laura Simpson, 29, home from a night out in her Volkswagen Beetle in Wilmslow, Cheshire.Miss Simpsons car had a faulty brake light so police pulled the footballer over.But Wayne was almost three times the legal limit.The former England captain was given a two-year driving ban and 100 hours community service.

title: boyzone to split after final album and farewell tour
story: The band temporarily split in 2000, with each member focusing on a solo career - with varied success.After a seven year hiatus, the band re-united in 2007, touring the following year.Alluding to the death of band member Stephen Gately in 2009, the statement said: "We've had some tough times too. The loss of Stephen left scars that we will carry as a band forever.""We came across a demo that he originally recorded for his solo album in 2002 and we've had the opportunity to re-work the song and add our harmonies alongside his lead vocal."It was a bittersweet experience to hear all our voices together again. It's the closest the five of us will ever get to being in a room together again making music."

title: hawkings words to be set to music and sent into space after westminster tribute
story: Readings were given by top figures from the science world, including astronaut Tim Peake, astronomer royal Martin Reece and Hawking's collaborator and Nobel prize winner Kip Thorn.Actor Benedict Cumberbatch, who played the physicist in a BBC drama, also gave a reading.Following the service, the physicist's words will be set to music and beamed into space by the European Space Agency, as a "message of peace and hope". The original six-minute composition was written by Greek composer Vangelis who was wrote the film score for film Chariots of Fire.Hawking's daughter Lucy explained that the broadcast will be sent towards "the nearest black hole, 1A 0620-00".CDs of the recording beamed into space will also be released for sale.During the service, the professor's ashes were also buried in Scientist's Corner, between the graves of Charles Darwin and Sir Isaac Newton.A black slate memorial stone lies above, bearing the inscription: "Here lies what was mortal of Stephen Hawking 1942 - 2018".Hawking's children thanked the abbey for the "distinguished" final resting place for their father.   Hawking's research into black holes and Hawking radiation shaped modern cosmology and helped ordinary people better understand the universe.His book, A Brief History Of Time, sold 10 million copies and was translated into 40 different languages.An open atheist, he was also known for his wicked sense of humour.The renowned scientist battled motor neurone disease for the majority of his life, which forced him to use an electronic voice synthesiser.Hawking died in March aged 76, with his funeral held in Cambridge, the city where he studied and worked.

title: proposed upskirting law blocked by tory mp
story: Blocking its progress only requires one MP to shout "object" when the title of a private member's bill is read out.Minister for women Victoria Atkins and Tory MP Will Quince were among those who cried "shame" after Sir Christopher's intervention.The bill will be debated next on 6 July, but will only take one dissenting voice to put another stop to its progress. Ms Hobhouse told Sky News it was a "petty thing to do"."I think it's very frustrating and annoying that one MP can block a consensus that had been built over several months," she said."It's really annoying we couldn't make progress."She added that "every month matters", pointing out festival season was approaching.Dawn Butler, Labour's shadow minister for women and equalities, said: "It's absolutely disgusting that a male Tory MP has blocked upskirting from becoming a criminal offence."If Theresa May is serious about tackling this vile practice, and injustices like sexism, she will need to show leadership and show there's no place in the Tory Party for Christopher Chope."Upskirting victim Gina Martin, 26, launched the campaign after two men took a picture up her skirt while at a festival in 2017.In a statement, Ms Martin admitted she knew Sir Christopher's scepticism was a "risk" but that "I'm positive and hopeful that he will become a supporter". A government spokesman said: "Whilst we are disappointed this Bill did not pass second reading today, we look forward to supporting these measures through the House at the earliest possible opportunity."Victims of upskirting have been found to be as young as 10 years old.

title: spotted dick renamed spotted richard to spare blushes in parliament
story: Tory MP Andrea Jenkyns was one of the first people to notice the reported change when she said she was offered a "Spotted Richard" by one server."I had to ask twice - just to be sure," she told the ."They have a traditional desserts section, which changes daily, so I asked what the dessert was and that's when they said it. I still have no idea why."Fellow Conservative MP Michael Fabricant could also not believe the reported change.He wrote on Twitter: "Call a dick a dick, I say!"

title: tories flagship benefit universal credit
story: NewsTories' flagship benefit Universal Credit torn apart in landmark NAO report - the 5 most shocking findingsUniversal Credit is branded a "shambles leaving a trail of destruction" after a National Audit Office (NAO) report. Here are the most damning findings&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomPolitical reporter00:01, 15 JUN 2018Updated12:01, 15 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFlagship Tory benefit Universal Credit is torn apart today in a damning report by the highly-respected National Audit Office. The spending watchdog found it has not delivered value for money, its rollout has been slower and costlier than promised, and it's caused hardship for many people. It's a devastating blow to the six-in-one benefit that was announced in 2010 as the pet project of former Tory welfare chief Iain Duncan Smith. It has since been taken over by a string of Work and Pension Secretaries and now rests in the hands of Tory Esther McVey. Labour MP Frank Field, who chairs the Work and Pensions Select Committee, today brands the benefit a “shambles, leaving a trail of destruction in its wake”. And campaigners have used the report to call for reform of the benefit, which has already cost the state &pound1.9bn to date.  Here are 5 of the most devastating findings in the report.  Last year along a quarter of new claims were not paid in full on time - a total of 113,000. And from January to October 2017, 40% of those affected by late payments waited for 11 weeks or more. A fifth of those with late payments waited almost five months. But despite improvements, in March this year 21% of new claimants did not receive their full entitlement on time with 13% receiving no payment on time. The DWP does not anticipate that delays will improve this year, the NAO said. And the DWP believes it will never achieve 100% payment on time because of the need to verify claimants' eligibility, the NAO warned. 2. It's taking far, far longer than expected  It's hard to believe it now, but Universal Credit was originally due to be rolled out fully by October 2017. Yet eight years after it was announced, only around 10% of the final expected caseload are currently claiming Universal Credit. There have been a string of delays and it's now due to end by March 2022. 3. It's could cost even more than the old system  The NAO said the system's running costs are currently &pound699 per claim - against an ambition of &pound173 by 2024. And it warned UC may cost more to administer than the system it replaced, which included job seeker's allowance, tax credit and housing benefit. Universal Credit has not delivered value for money and it is uncertain that it ever will, the NAO said. The project is not value for money now, and that its future value for money is unproven. 4. Its entire selling point could be an empty promise  Universal Credit was sold to the nation on the basis it will encourage people into work. That's because it is designed to make work pay by ensuring people aren't accidentally penalised for every extra hour they work.  However, the NAO said we doubt it will ever be possible for the DWP to measure if Universal Credit has increased the number of people in work. 5. It drives people to food banks - and the DWP's in denial  Since the introduction of UC there have been increases in rent arrears and the use of food banks, the NAO reported. The watchdog added private landlords have become reluctant to rent homes to people on the flahship benefit. In three of the four areas the NAO visited that had proper data, foodbank use increased quicker after Universal Credit was rolled out fully. But the report warned the DWP does not accept that Universal Credit has caused hardship among claimants. The Department has not shown sufficient sensitivity towards some claimants, the NAO said. It does not know how many claimants are having problems with the programme or have suffered hardship. Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office, warned the DWP has shown a lack of regard in failing to understand the hardship faced by some claimants. But we're so far down the track, there's no way it can stop  NAO chief Amyas Morse added: The benefits that it set out to achieve through Universal Credit, such as increased employment and lower administration costs, are unlikely to be achieved. Yet the Department has little realistic alternative but to continue with the programme and hopefully learn from past mistakes.”   How have campaigners reacted?

title: tory esther mcvey reveals 1000
story: NewsTory Esther McVey reveals 1,000 people will be given higher benefits in ANOTHER humiliating climbdownWe now know how many people it will affect&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporterMikey SmithPolitical reporter11:01, 15 JUN 2018Updated11:28, 15 JUN 2018News (Image: AFP)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Up to 1,000 people are to be granted higher benefits in another humiliating climbdown revealed by Tory Welfare secretary Esther McVey .  The Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) announced last month they would withdraw from a court battle with two chronically ill people, AN and JM, who wanted higher Personal Independence Payments (PIP). One of the pair is severely diabetic and has to be watched at night to avoid slipping into a deadly coma. The pair's lawyers argued that this need for an observer counted as therapy - which would, in turn, give the claimant higher PIP. Ms McVey today confirmed the DWP had backed down in the case, and the two people involved will be paid extra PIP within days.

title: tory mps philip davies sir
story: NewsTory MPs Philip Davies and Sir Christopher Chope block progress on upskirting ban by talking for four hoursThere were cries of "shame" as the pair took advantage of archaic Commons rules to "talk out" a day's worth of bills&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter16:52, 15 JUN 2018Updated18:30, 15 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo Tory MPs blocked the progress of a bill that would have made taking 'upskirt' photos a specific criminal offence by talking for four hours. MPs cried shame as progress of the bill, which has cross-party support and is backed by the Government, was delayed until at July because of the antics of Shipley MP Philip Davies and Christchurch MP Sir Christopher Chope. The pair have frequently taken advantage of an archaic quirk of Commons rules in which MPs are prevented from voting on a bill on a Friday if the debate goes on past 2.30pm. There is no time limit on members' speeches on a Friday, effectively allowing them to talk for as long as they want. Their marathon speeches were during the first debate of the day, on a bill to tighten regulation on the use of force in Mental Health Units.  Davies addressed more than 100 amendments put to the Mental Health Units (Use of Force Bill) at report stage by MPs, including several of his own, during an address which lasted almost two-and-a-half hours. The Shipley MP clashed frequently with his frontbench over the need for some of his amendments, at one stage branding ministers shameful after being told one was unnecessary. Other MPs also voiced their frustration at the length of his speech, which finished after 148 minutes. As his speech hit the two-hour mark, Liberal Democrat former health minister Norman Lamb said: I have a very real concern - and I don't think it's his intention, but I hope it isn't - that we could end up this being talked out today, and the risk then that this Bill is lost. That would be a tragedy if that happened.  Mr Davies insisted the Bill would not be lost, and would progress on a future Friday sitting in a better state once the Government has looked at amendments. Mr Davies pushed two of his amendments to a vote, both linked to training in appropriate use of force. Amendment 11 was defeated by 47 votes to eight, majority 39, and amendment 12 was defeated by 49 votes to three, majority 46. The Bill later progressed to third reading, the final Commons stage, where it was talked out by Conservative former minister Sir Christopher Chope.  The Christchurch MP was still speaking as the clock struck 2.30pm, meaning it had not formally completed the stage as debate was still considered to be ongoing. It will return to the Commons on July 6, where third reading debate will resume. After the 2.30pm deadline, there is an opportunity for bills to be waved through the initial debate stage without a vote - as long as nobody in the chamber voices an objection. Every bill on today's order paper was either not moved, or blocked by an objection and delayed until July 6th - when they will be sent to the bottom of the list of bills to be debated. He is an absolute pr**k: Reaction to the bill being blocked In a statement, campaigner Gina Martin said: I am obviously extremely upset and disappointed that Sir (Christopher) Chope decided to object on this vitally important bill for the women of England and Wales. I remain positive, though. We knew this was a risk - but I now stand with powerful, passionate women and men behind me, and I am confident that (junior minister) Lucy Frazer is committed to - and will - close this gap in the law.  Ryan (Whelan, her lawyer), Wera (Hobhouse MP) and I will be meeting with Lucy shortly to discuss how we move forward together. Ryan and I have just spoken with Sir Christopher and he has agreed to meet with the two of us to discuss the bill.  I'm positive and hopeful that he will become a supporter.

title: what upskirting meaning law explained
story: NewsWhat is upskirting? The meaning and law explained after Tory MPs block bid to make the photos illegalSir Christopher Chope objected to the Voyeurism (Offences) Bill which would make it illegal for offenders to take a picture under someone's clothing without their consent.&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPaul Cockerton16:59, 15 JUN 2018Updated17:00, 15 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe campaign to criminalise upskirting took a blow today when a Tory grandee blocked the bill in Parliament  There were cries of shame! as Sir Christopher Chope objected to the Voyeurism (Offences) Bill which would make it illegal for offenders to take a picture under someone's clothing without their consent.  Here are some of the key questions surrounding the issue: What is upskirting? The cruel and invasive craze involves perpetrators using cameras to take images or video up victims' clothing without their consent to see their genitals or underwear.. While the vast majority of known cases involve men targeting women, the roles sometimes can be reversed. The first available data on the prevalence of upskirting showed victims as young as 10 complaining to police. Currently, there is no specific law in place banning the practice. But haven't people been convicted of upskirting? While Scotland has had its own law on upskirting for almost a decade, the law in England and Wales has not adapted to advances in technology. Currently, anyone in England and Wales who falls victim to the cruel craze can explore possible convictions for public disorder or indecency. Campaigners want a specific offence. Why could campaigner Gina Martin not prosecute at the time?  Her lawyer, Ryan Whelan, said: Decisions to prosecute rest with the authorities, not the victim. Under the current law the man who upskirted Gina could have potentially been prosecuted for outraging public decency. The problem is that prosecuting upskirters for outraging public decency is not appropriate. There are two primary reasons for this. First the offence of outraging public decency does not apply in all instances of upskirting. This means that women are not protected in all circumstances. Second, the offence of outraging public decency is inappropriate as it fails to reflect the sexual nature of the offence and/or the fact that the harm is caused to the individual (rather than the public). These positions are not controversial. Leading authorities in the field agree with my client: upskirting is a gap in the law and the only way to solve it is by legislation. What would the new law say? The new law would bring the punishment for upskirting in line with other existing voyeurism offences, and the changes will see offenders face a maximum of two years in prison. It would also allow this intrusive behaviour to be treated as a sexual offence and, with Government amendments, ensure that the most serious offenders are made subject to notification requirements - commonly referred to as the sex offenders register. There will be a threshold, meaning those who commit the more serious offences - especially those designed to cause alarm, distress or humiliation - are dealt with more seriously. Who is backing it?  The Government stated its support for making upskirting a specific criminal offence hours before Lib Dem MP Wera Hobhouse's Private Members' Bill. It was the crucial backing campaigners - including upskirting victim Gina Martin, 26, and her legion of famous supporters - were hoping for after months of meetings with the Ministry of Justice to thrash out terms for suitable legislation. High-profile public figures - such as television presenters Holly Willoughby, Dermot O'Leary and Laura Whitmore - have also been open about their support for the campaign. How was it blocked?

title: childish mps spark pudding name
story: NewsSpotted Dick gets a rebrand in Parliament because 'childish' MPs can't copeA classic pudding has been renamed for diners at the Houses of Parliament to avoid embarrassment&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCourtney Pochin11:31, 15 JUN 2018Updated13:36, 15 JUN 2018NewsSpotted Dick has been rebranded 'Spotted Richard' by Parliament staff (Image: REX/Shutterstock)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's a popular British pudding that's been around since the 1840s. Spotted Dick has been a source of amusement for diners for years, but it seems none are finding it more amusing than MPs - so much so that waiters won't say the name of the dessert in the Houses of Parliament. Staff working in Strangers' Dining Room in the Commons have taken to calling the pud 'Spotted Richard' to save those dining from their blushes.  Four staff working in the restaurant confirmed the name change, reports The  .  They added that this was to avoid causing a stir among guests.  However regular diners in the restaurant have branded the rename silly on social media. Conservative MP for Morley and Outwood, Andrea Jenkins told The  she had to bite on her lip to stop from laughing when a waiter offered her a slice of Spotted Richard earlier this week. She added: I had to ask twice, just to be sure. They have a traditional desserts selection, which changes daily, so I asked what the dessert was and that's when they said it. I still have no idea why. Other MPs have not taken the situation so lightly. Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage blasted the rebrand, calling it PC baloney.  Social media users have also chimed in on the conversation, with many of the opinion it is a childish move. One Twitter user wrote: If some MPs are giggling at Spotted Dick as a pudding then this is proof that the HoP really are like a primary school playground - absolutely pathetic and embarrassing. Another added: What will be next - not being able to fill tarts with cream? A spokesman for the House of Commons denied that the name had been changed but later added: We are not always able to control how staff may refer to dishes.

title: duchess cambridge received seriously fancy
story: NewsDuchess of Cambridge has received some seriously fancy presents from the Royal family over the yearsLucky Kate has been given some very lavish gifts from her generous in-laws&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor17:19, 15 JUN 2018NewsLucky old her (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe know that the Queen gets joke presents from her nearest and dearest every year at Christmas. After all, what do you even get the woman who already has everything, bar a unicorn or the elixir of life? But this doesn't mean that the rest of the family get novelty toilet seats and whoopee cushions.  Take the Duchess of Cambridge for example.  Since joining the royal ranks, she's been showered with the sort of lavish gifts the rest of us can only ever dream of.  Let's take a look and see what the best ones have been.   1. The Cartier Ballon Bleu watch  Traditionally, your third wedding anniversary symbol used to be leather. Then it got updated to glass or crystal. Not if you're royal though. For her third wedding anniversary in 2014, Kate got the Ballon Bleu de Cartier watch.  Set with tiny sapphires, it matches her engagement ring - also another high-rent gift - and also has echoes of Princess Diana, who loved Cartier watches.    2. Her engagement ring Arguably her first bit of regal bling, Kate's engagement ring is now believed to be priceless, due to its historical significance. Once belonging to Princess Diana, it's made up of a band featuring a 12-carat sapphire surrounded by 14 diamonds and set in 18-carat white gold, and spawned countless imitations.  3. Anmer Hall from the Queen This one will put every gift you've ever received in the shade. As the ultimate wedding present, the Queen gave Kate and William their very own stately home. No scrimping and saving to get on the property ladder for this couple. Set on the Queen's Sandringham estate, Anmer Hall boasts ten bedrooms, a swimming pool and private tennis court and was recently refurbished to the tune of several millions of pounds.  4. A white and yellow diamond jewellery set from Prince Charles Proving she's very much in there with her in-laws, Kate received a set of art deco diamond jewellery as a wedding gift in 2011 from Prince Charles. It features a white and yellow diamond bracelet, earrings and ring, all of which Kate has been seen in on several occasions. 5. A charm bracelet from the Duchess of Cornwall Lucky Kate must need a vault for all of her baubles. As another wedding gift - this time from the Duchess of Cornwall - Kate received a gold link charm bracelet with some very sweet details. It features a gold disc engraved with a C for Catherine and a coronet on one side, and a crown and C for Camilla on the other.    6. Sapphire and diamond earrings from Prince William We know they married for love, but Kate's wedding proved to be pretty lucrative for her! Around the time of their nuptials in 2011, William gave Kate a pair of matching sapphire and diamond earrings, which she then customised into drop earrings and debuted them on her tour of Canada.  7. Green amethyst earrings from William Clearly a generous spouse, for their first Christmas as a married couple, William gifted Kate a pair of green amethyst earrings from one of her favourite designers, Kiki McDonough. The earrings are surrounded by diamonds and set in 18-carat yellow gold, and Kate wore them for the first time for the church service on Christmas Day in 2011.

story: NewsLove Island fan, 11, 'kicks off' after parents ban her from watching show sparking 999 emergency police responseLeicestershire Police classed the call as a ‘Grade One’ emergency and sent officers with lights flashing and sirens blaring to the family home in Coalville&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMartin Fricker14:25, 15 JUN 2018Updated14:50, 15 JUN 2018NewsThe schoolgirl was reportedly upset because she is not allowed to watch the hit show (Image: ITV2)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily Love Island updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPolice raced to the home of an 11-year-old whose parents dialled 999 when she “kicked off” after being told she could not watch Love Island. title: married fairground workers running bouncy
story: NewsMarried fairground workers running bouncy castle which blew away killing girl, seven, jailed for three yearsSummer Grant passed away in hospital after she was rescued from the inflatable at an Easter Fair in Harlow, Essex&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHannah KaneDanya BazaraaNews Reporter14:46, 15 JUN 2018Updated15:30, 15 JUN 2018NewsSummer died in hospital after attending an Easter Fair in Harlow, Essex (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMarried fairground workers running a bouncy castle which blew away resulting in the death of a seven-year-old girl have both been jailed for three years. Summer Grant passed away in hospital after she was rescued from the inflatable at an Easter Fair in Harlow, Essex, on March 26, 2016. Husband and wife fairground workers William and Shelby Thurston were handed a sentence of three years each today.  Summer's mum Cara Blackie has told Chelmsford Crown Court today how she screamed when a nurse phoned her while she was in a taxi to tell her that her daughter had died. In a heartbreaking statement, she said: I never thought that my Summer playing and having fun on the bouncy castle would end her young life. Outside court, police read out a statement by Cara which said: The feeling I had leaving Summer in hospital alone will be with me forever.  Her dad Lee Grant's devastating statement in court said: When Summer died, I felt as if I died too. I felt as if I had nothing left to live for because she was my beautiful angel. DCI Daniel Stoten later read a further comment from Lee which said: I just want to cry and cry and for someone to tell me that this is a really long and horrible dream. But it is not, it is very real and it hurts so much. A court heard how the day after her death, younger sister Lily was told that Summer was up in the sky with the angels.  Her mum lay with her in bed and tried to explain what had happened but 'didn't understand what she was saying'.  That night, her mother saw her staring out the window in their hotel room. She said: “I’m saying goodnight to Summer.” Cara said: It was killing me inside, but I knew I had to be strong for her sake.  During sentencing remarks, a court was told: It does not bear thinking about what that little girl went through inside that bouncy castle. A trial previously heard the inflatable rolled up to 15 times in the air after it came off the ground. It was said to have blown 15ft in the air and landed 300m away.  William and Shelby Thurston had denied manslaughter by gross negligence and a health and safety offence at a previous hearing at Chelmsford Crown Court.  But after a three-week trial a jury found them both guilty of manslaughter by gross negligence last month. The couple, from Wilburton, near Ely, Cambridgeshire, were also found guilty of failure to discharge a duty under section 3 of the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974. During the sentencing remarks today, a judge told the Thurstons they had put children at real risk of harm. The judge added that it was only good fortune that Summer's sister Lily was not also inside the bouncy castle, Essex Live reports.   Her mum Cara's statement in court today said: I was home watching a film when my phone rang. It was Tasha Stephens and she was crying and not making much sense. I could not make sense what was going on. My heart sank. I just wanted to be there for my little girl. We called a taxi to take us to Harlow. All sorts of things were going through my head but not that my daughter would die. After being in the taxi for 15 minutes a nurse called and told me Summer had died. I screamed. Cara described how before Summer's funeral, she painted her daughter's nails blue - her favourite colour. She also put her glittery shoes in the coffin - the ones that Summer wanted to wear on her first night out. The court heard that since Summer's death, Cara has suffered from anxiety and depression which has made everyday life very hard.  The schoolgirl, from Norwich, had been at the fair with her father Lee and other family members. We all have to live with this for the rest of our lives,” a statement on behalf of Lee read out in the courtroom today said. Lee described as Summer as the most beautiful and polite little girl you could ever know who was loved by everyone she met.  She did not deserve what happened, and this should never happen again to anyone, a statement by Lee read out by police outside court said.  Family members of the Thurstons burst into tears as the sentences were passed. In the sentencing remarks, the fairground workers were told: This was not simple negligence. This was gross negligence. Your breaches of duty were not just serious mistakes. Your conduct was so bad that in the jury’s view, it must be regarded as criminal. At the heart was your failure to have any sensible regard for the weather. High winds had been predicted for days. You knew that or should have known that. You were putting your customers, and by customers I mean children like Summer and Lily, at real risk of harm.”  The judge said the fairground workers had failed to ensure the dome was adequately anchored to the ground and to monitor the weather conditions to ensure they were suitable.  They were told: You were both directly responsible for this. You failed to ensure that the dome was properly secured to the ground. The evidence as to the number of anchorage points out of the available 17 that were in fact used is somewhat opaque. That being so, I cannot conclude that you failed to use all 17 and I proceed on the basis you did. But you did not use the upper four anchorage points with which the dome was fitted.  I find as a fact that that is what those tags were for and I find that you were in breach of your duty under the Health and Safety at Work Act in not doing so. The judge paid tribute to the dignity shown by Summer's family during the trial.  Shortly before 4.15pm the East of England Ambulance service had received a call and they attended with commendable speed, the court heard.  Summer was taken to the Princess Alexandra Hospital by ambulance where tragically, she died from multiple injuries she sustained as the dome careered down the hill.  Dad Lee had run after the inflatable, which was lifted off the ground by wind while Summer was playing on it, jurors have previously been told. Ms Ayling earlier told the court that Mr Grant ran after the SuperDome as it lifted into the air. The prosecution lawyer said: “Lee Grant heard his mother scream ‘No!’. He turned and saw the dome inflatable had lifted into the air, appeared to hit a caravan before flipping over. “He shouted: ‘My daughter is in that’, and ran after it, but it was moving to fast for him to catch it. “Another woman who was at pet’s corner could see the top of the SuperDome as it was lifting in the air. “It was cartwheeling and only stopped when it crashed into a fence at the bottom of the park.” Summer suffered serious injuries during the incident and died just a few hours later. Speaking after the guilty verdicts, Nicola Rutter from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) said: William and Shelby Thurston failed to ensure that the bouncy castle was adequately anchored to the ground and failed to monitor the weather conditions to ensure that it was safe to have it in use. They denied their actions were negligent but the CPS and the police built a strong case, together with assistance from the Health and Safety Executive, and demonstrated to the jury that the Thurstons had breached their duty of care to Summer. Our thoughts are with Summer's family and friends.

title: meghan markle give up favourite
story: NewsWhy Meghan Markle had to give up her favourite food after marrying Prince HarryThe Duchess of Sussex has to follow strict dietary rules after joining the royal family - and that includes giving up seafood&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill14:54, 15 JUN 2018Updated17:07, 15 JUN 2018NewsMeghan Markle has had to give up her favourite food after marrying Prince Harry (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle is now a fully fledged member of the royal family and that means living by their rules - which includes giving up her favourite food. The former Suits actress, now the Duchess of Sussex, has to follow strict dietary rules following her wedding to Prince Harry last month. Royal Butler Grant Harrold has revealed the royal family do not eat seafood out of fear of getting food poisoning.  He told the Express : “It is a very sensible move to abandon having seafood when out and about on public duties.  “We don't want a member of the Royal family having a serious reaction to food poisoning, especially if she is on an overseas tour.”  No doubt Meghan was disappointed by this restriction in her diet as she has previously spoken about her love of seafood. The 36-year-old told The New Potato magazine that her ideal food day would involve lots of seafood. She said: “A leisurely dinner of seafood and pasta, and a negroni to cap off the night.” However, seafood isn't in the only restriction as other luxurious dishes are also banned.  Mr Harrold added: “As well as shellfish, it would also be quite appropriate for foods such as foie gras to be avoided.”  Andrew Farquharson, Deputy Master at Clarence House, also told the  : “The Prince of Wales has a policy that his chefs should not buy foie gras.”  This is believed to be due to animal welfare concerns rather than a dietary restriction. title: mum finds mysterious sharp object
story: NewsMum finds 'mysterious sharp object' in Asda nappy she fears could have hurt 'precious' baby daughterHorrified Laura Ashton, 22, claims she discovered the object beneath the lining of her baby's nappy - part of a multi-pack she had bought from Asda near her home in Stafford&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByOlive Loveridge-Greene11:35, 15 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAsda has launched an investigation after a mum claimed she found a sharp object hiding inside one of its nappies. Laura Ashton, 22, was getting ready for the school-run with daughters Millie, five, and Gracie-May, one, when she says she made the shocking discovery. Noticing her toddler needed changing, the mum-of-two rushed into the living room and picked up the next nappy out of the &pound4.98 Asda Little Angels 72-pack. But the support worker from Stafford, Staffordshire, explained how she noticed a small dark mark underneath the topsheet of the disposable nappy. Tearing the nappy open Laura was shocked to pull out a sharp, mysterious object.  She has since called on safer regulations to be put in place in the manufacturing process of babies’ nappies. “I had just finished getting Millie’s bag ready for school before I realised Gracie-May needed changing, she said. “I walked into the living room and picked out the next nappy from the pack. “As I opened it up I noticed something dark in the middle so rubbed my fingers across it.  “It felt quite pointy so I told Millie to film me opening it up. “After a few seconds I managed to tear out a sharp, dark object. It felt quite light but it was really sharp. “At first I thought it was a piece of machinery but God knows what it was. “Millie was shouting ‘chuck it in the fire’. We then started going through a few more to see if anything else dangerous was lurking in there. “I’m just so shocked. If I hadn’t spotted it that could have pierced through and really hurt Gracie-May.” Laura contacted Asda after finding the object on Monday morning. “I phoned up customer services to make a complaint and they just told me to go back to my local store”, she said. “I marched down there and was just handed another 72-pack of nappies. As if I’m going to use them! “It’s outrageous. I’ll never buy them again.” Laura shared her terrifying discovery on Facebook, clocking up 430,000 views and 6,000 shares.  She said: “I did it to raise awareness among my family and friends as I was just outraged with what had happened. “You just don’t know how many times this has happened and people have let it slide. Others mums have messaged me thanking me. “There needs to be safer regulations as babies are so precious.”

title: new mum becomes sisters bridesmaid
story: NewsWoman gives birth then makes it to church to be sister's bridesmaid six hours later (and baby went too)Emily Chell was rushed to hospital and gave birth to her son just hours before the wedding - but managed to make it to the church on time with her newborn in tow&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMatt JacksonElaine McCahill13:18, 15 JUN 2018Updated16:02, 15 JUN 2018NewsNew mum Emily Chell gave birth to her son at 7am on the day of her sister's wedding and still made it to the church to be a bridesmaid (Image: Samantha Jayne Photography /SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new mum who gave birth just hours before her sister's wedding managed to make it to the church on time to be a bridesmaid - and with her newborn baby boy in tow. Emily Chell, 27, went into labour in the early hours of the day of the wedding and was rushed to Royal Stoke University Hospital to give birth. She had been staying at a hotel near her sister Katie's wedding venue when her son decided he wanted to be at the wedding too, reports Stoke on Trent Live. Despite being in the throws of labour Emily kept insisting to doctors and nurses that she would make it out in time for the ceremony.  Emily gave birth to son Brody at 7.10am on the day of the wedding – and the race was on get them back to South Cheshire. Emily said: “Brody wasn’t due for another three weeks. I was looking forward to the wedding and everyone was taking bets he would be born on the day but I didn’t think it would happen. “When we were in the hospital I kept saying I wanted to get to the church on time. The doctors kept telling me if there were no complications and he was born by 7am we would make it.” The new arrival and his parents managed to get to Congleton’s Alcumlow Hall Farm where Emily got changed and made it to the church in Astbury at 12.55pm – just ten minutes late.  She said: “My mum hadn’t even met Brody until we made it to the church. “When my partner Wayne walked in everyone cheered him. We’ve had loads of messages and it has been a bit of a crazy week. “On the day we went to the reception but then had to go home because we hadn’t actually had the time to feed Brody.” Emily's dad Darren Chell, aged 53, was writing his wedding speech in the early hours of the morning when Wayne called him to tell him what was happening. He said: “I’d finished writing my speech at 2.30am and thought I would finally get some sleep but Wayne rang and said Emily had gone into labour. “Later on I was in the car with Katie, we were running late, and Emily rang saying she was five minutes away, I thought ‘you must be joking’. “I told the venue to get her bridesmaid’s dress ready. We were shocked she made it but it was magical.” Bride Katie said she was overwhelmed by the experience but was pleased her sister - and nephew – made it for her big day.

story: NewsShocking picture shows 'Spice zombies' slumped on pavement in town centre as children play nearbyThe image was taken on June 12 in Bridgend, Wales, and appears to show three men 'experiencing the devastating effects that alcohol or drugs can have upon individuals'&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMegan Griffiths14:03, 15 JUN 2018Updated15:55, 15 JUN 2018NewsThis picture has been circulating social media (Image: Copyright unknown)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA shocking picture shows three men believed to have taken Spice slumped in a busy town centre. One shopper, who asked not to be named, told Wales Online : It's terrible what I saw. There was kids in the background and walking past.  The original photo has been shared over 1,400 times and received comments of outrage and concern. One user wrote: I'm too scared to walk around there in the day. Absolutely disgusting.  Another wrote: Shocking and upsetting and the fact Bridgend has already got a bad reputation, how are the good people supposed to make our town better? Clearly these people have their issues. Go on take your last ounce of respect and do it somewhere else. Spice is usually a mix of herbs or shredded plant material with man-made mind-altering chemicals sprayed on to them. It is marketed as an alternative to cannabis by drug dealers but, chemically, the two drugs are very different. Cannabis comes from a plant, but Spice is a “synthetic cannabinoid”, a family of around 700 research chemicals. Although it is sold to look like cannabis, the effects come from the chemicals.  Because there are over 700 types, any of which can be used to create Spice, the effects of the drug can vary massively depending on which compounds have been used in its production. Only last month, Logan Johns-Evans, 11, was left like a zombie after it was claimed that a rolly cigarette he had been smoking was laced with the synthetic drug without his knowledge. Spice used to be available in shops and online and was sold as a so-called legal-high, but it was made illegal in 2016 under the Psychoactive Substances Act. South Wales Police have said: We are aware of a photo circulating on social media which appears to show a small number of men in Bridgend Town Centre experiencing the devastating effects that alcohol or drugs can have upon individuals.

title: man who tossed live alligator

Joshua James was picking up an order at Wendy's in Royal Palm Beach, Florida, when the alleged incident took place. title: dog owner spots ghost great
story: NewsDog owner spots 'ghost of her Great Dane in curtains' just weeks after he diedMichelle Creighton, 44, says she was comforted by seeing the ghost of her beloved pet on the living room curtains at her home in Manitoba, Canada&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMollie Mansfield11:55, 15 JUN 2018NewsThe Great Dane's ghost appeared in the living room curtains, according to his owner (Image: Caters News Agency)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pooch lover is convinced that she saw the ghost of her dead dog in her living room curtains just weeks after he passed away. Michelle Creighton, 44, has struggled to come to terms with the loss of her six-year-old great dane, Oakley, after he died in April. However she believes her late pooch wasn’t far away, as she saw his ‘ghost’ on the living room curtains one evening. Despite the sight being eerie to some, Michelle found great comfort in seeing her dog on the curtains and believes that it proves his presence is still with her.  Michelle, from Manitoba, Canada, said: “When I first saw the shadow I thought my eyes were playing tricks on me, so I just started at it. “But then it clicked and I couldn’t believe how much it looked like my great dane, Oakley. “I quickly took some photographs because I didn’t think anyone would believe me! “I even got up and opened the curtains, and the shape changed and I could no longer see the shape of my dog – I got immediate goose bumps!”  Despite her initial shock, Michelle explains that the sighting has brought her comfort since – as she believes it shows her dog is always around her. She added: “The sighting made me feel at ease and I decided to take it as a sign of him being ok and that he’s where he’s supposed to be – at home with me. “I haven’t stopped smiling since and nothing beats that feeling – I believe their energy is still here. “When Oakley passed away I was in complete shock and I cried for days because everything reminded me of him and my house was never the same again.

title: confirmed dundee united complete signing of belgian defender frans
story: Dundee United have confirmed the capture of ex Partick Thistle defender Frederic Frans.The 29-year-old has signed a two-year-deal with the Tannadice side.The big centre back played for the Jags between 2014 and 2016 but left to join Lierse SK in his homeland.The side went bust leaving Frans a free agent and drew the attention of a number of sides.United managed to fight off competition from the likes of his old side Partick and Ross county for his signature.Today boss Csaba Laszlo said: “I was very keen to bring Freddy to the club this summer and I am delighted to have secured his services.&#8220He brings us experience, strength and height. He can play with both feet, is good in the air and a great person to have in the dressing room.”The player himself added: “I am thrilled to be back in Scotland and to sign for Dundee United. It is a beautiful club with an amazing fan base and I am fully focused on helping us achieve our ambitions.&#8221

title: dundee interested in ex hamilton accie ali crawford
story: Dundee are eyeing up a move for former Hamilton playmaker Ali Crawford – though they face stiff competition for his signature.The 26-year-old left Accies at the end of last season after 11 years at the club.Dens gaffer Neil McCann is keen to add more to his attack and Crawford would fit the bill as a creative force for his front line.English side Blackpool, however, are also keen on the player.He stated when leaving New Douglas Park he wanted to head down south to further his career, so a move to the English League One would be attractive.Gary Bowyer’s Seasiders finished in 12th spot last season.Also in the frame are Hibs after manager Neil Lennon admitted he was keen on Crawford, while Motherwell have also made advances.The attacking midfielder certainly has options to choose from for his next destination but has indicated he will take his time over the decision.Meanwhile, Dundee’s pursuit of Peterborough defender Jack Baldwin has recieved a boost.The Posh have snapped up Ross County defender Jason Naismith.The Staggies full-back impressed last season despite the Highland side finishing bottom of the Premiership pile and suffering relegation as a result.And Steve Evans has swooped for another Scotsman after grabbing Dee midfielder Mark O’Hara at the end of last month on a free transfer.Signing Naismith has seen Dundee target Baldwin transfer listed at London Road with his services no longer required.The asking price of £200,000, however, is still in place which could put an end to the Dark Blues’ interest.

title: dundee people apprentice takes silver in national competition
story: A Dundee electrical apprentice has beaten 500 others from around Scotland to take second at a national competition.Paul Anderson, who is studying at Dundee and Angus College, recently competed in the electrotechnical Modern Apprenticeship competition (eMAc).The competition is organised and run by the Scottish Electrical Charitable Training Trust (SECTT) and aims to recognise the achievements of Scotland’s apprentices as well as demonstrate the level of skill and expertise that will be gained through an apprenticeship.&#8220Coming second in this competition is a massive achievement for Paul as this competition is open to all of the SECTT 3rd Year apprentices of which there is 500 across Scotland,&#8221 said Chris Parker, Electrical Course Leader at Dundee and Angus College.&#8220All the staff within the Electrical department at Dundee and Angus College are proud of his achievements and Paul deserves lots of credit for the hard work and determination he has shown not just for this competition but throughout his apprenticeship.&#8221The top apprentices from all across the UK will then be invited to go forward and compete in the UK skills competition final that is being organised by WorldSkills UK.&#8220It is hopeful that Paul has scored high enough to be selected for the UK skills finals,&#8221 Chris said.Paul added: &#8220I would like to thank McGill’s for giving me my apprenticeship and giving me a great start to my career.&#8220I would also like to thank everyone that helped and supported me throughout this competition.&#8220I am so pleased I won silver for apprentice of the year for Scotland and hopefully be able to compete in the UK final.&#8221

title: dundee people big lunch marks dundee mans 18 day walk home
story: Hundreds of people welcomed home a Dundee man who had spent 18 days walking to the city.Angus McLeod was taking part in the Big Walk, which kicked off on May 16 in Morecambe.The event saw four teams set off across the UK, each walking home over the course of 18 days.The project aimed to connect people and communities and also invited them to take part in the UK’s annual get-together for neighbours by hosting a Big Lunch event on Sunday.Angus celebrated his return by hosting his Big Lunch at Discovery Point, where he was welcomed by his family and friends.He said: “I was expecting the walking to be a challenge, but it has been so much more.”

title: dundee people got a cool activity for the singing kenyan kids coming to dundee
story: When Kasia Thomson finished a lecture early and decided to see a show, she didn&#8217t realise she would fall in love with the group of children from Africa.Two years on, after another visit from the group last year, the 24-year-old is now organising a stay in Dundee for the group who will be back in Scotland in September and November.She first heard about the Singing Children of Africa in 2016 at a concert her cousin was at.&#8220I was meant to be in a lecture and it finished early so I went to the concert,&#8221 she said.&#8220They were singing songs and they were absolutely amazing.&#8221The fundraising concert was followed by a talk from Maureen McIntyre who started Educate The Kids charity and runs the school in Kenya which the group is from.&#8220From there on I just fell in love with the children,&#8221 Kasia said.Last year, she helped organise the tour of Dundee including a visit to HMS Discovery, a mini concert in the Overgate, lunch at Hampton by Hilton, and a party at the Univeristy of Dundee.The students also had a chance to be engineers and scientists for a day and performed at halftime at Tannadice Park.&#8220They&#8217re so interested in everything so they were United&#8217s biggest fans that day,&#8221 Kasia said.With 28 students coming in September this year, Kasia said she was beginning to plan this year&#8217s events and decided to ask the community for any suggestions.She said they were planning on repeating some of the events from last time, as some of the children hadn&#8217t been to Scotland before, but was also looking for other things as well.&#8220If you can help us in any way make the children&#8217s time in Dundee more memorable, whether it&#8217s providing a venue for a show, lunch or dinner for the child, a fun day out, anything at all, get in touch,&#8221 she said.

story: A company has advertised &#8220an exciting opportunity has arisen to join a progressive optical company that continues to invest in its people, equipment and R&ampD to service a global photonics market&#8221.The company has enjoyed considerable growth over recent years as it continues to expand its product offering to its globally based customers, it said.&#8220As part of its expansion plan the business is looking to recruit individuals to complement its growth who can enjoy a career in an open but technically challenging environment.&#8220One such opening is within our optics manufacturing area where we are looking for a highly skilled individual to join us to support our business growth.&#8220This position offers variety and challenge in an environment where the prospective candidate can excel and grow.&#8220We are prepared to offer an attractive remuneration package commensurate with the correct experience and skills.&#8221For more information, including how to apply, visit the Jobs in Scotland page.

title: dundee people primary schools lgbt charter a scots first
story: A Dundee primary school will be the first in Scotland to receive the LGBT Charter award later this month.Downfield’s award will be presented by LGBT Youth Scotland at an all-school assembly on Monday June 18.The event will feature speeches, songs and a 400-person rainbow flag made of coloured cardboard.A spokesman for LGBT Youth Scotland said: “Downfield Primary School received overwhelming support from parents during their Charter journey, with some writing letters to the head teacher reflecting on the positive impact it had on their children.“An equality and diversity team of nine pupils took a lead role in reviewing and developing the school’s policies, a process that involved the ideas and opinions of young people every step of the way.”The LGBT Charter has been awarded to organisations including Barnardo’s Scotland and Scottish Women’s Aid, as well as 18 high schools across the country. It represents a serious and ongoing commitment to improving and evidencing an organisation’s policies and values around LGBTI inclusion.The spokesman added: “LGBT Youth Scotland provide comprehensive training for staff members.“We also guide each organisation’s LGBT Charter team through the collation of a folder of evidence that tells the story of their journey and roadmaps the future.”

title: dundee people teacher takes gruelling cycle raise cash school
story: A teacher has cycled 185 miles in one day to raise money for his school.Anthony Revell, from Dundee’s Kingspark School, pedalled the distance to raise money for the development of the school’s outdoor learning yurt.The cycle represented one mile for every pupil and he aimed to raise £1,850 – a target he is close to making.Anthony said: “It was surprisingly OK. We had loads of support from parents and carers so that was quite motivating. The support has been amazing.“It was quite a long day but really good fun and for a worthwhile cause.”The cycle started at 6.30am from St Andrews and finished there about 12 hours later.His journey took him through the local authorities that have pupils at the school.

title: dundee people westports scout bar reopens as ballys two years after closure
